SEARCH
Package math.core

Class Digit

java.lang.Object
math.core.Notationer
math.core.Digit
All Implemented Interfaces:
Comparable<Digit>
public class Digit extends Notationer implements Comparable<Digit>
Turns any primitive given number or a real number on a string into a full notationed readable number

Example of use:



		Digit n = new Digit(1.23456E7);

		System.out.print(n);//12,345,600
Since:
v0.0.1

    The boolean isNegative represents if the number is either negative or positive, true for negative, false for positive.
    boolean
    notation
    The boolean notation represents if the number is either using the decimal point notation or the dot decimal notation, true for DPN, false for DDN.

  • Method Details

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Implements the String format() function from extended class Notationer to print the number on a readable notation using the attributes this.integerPart, this.decimalPart and this.notation as paramethers for such function. The return values will be either negative or positive depending on the state of the attribute this.isNegative.
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      String Returns a full notationed readable number.
      Since:
      v0.0.1
      See Also:
      • Notationer.format(String, String, boolean)

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(Digit n)
      Implements the int compareTo(Object) function from implemented class Comparable to compare the instances.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit(1.23456E7);
			Digit m = new Digit("89");

			int result = n.compareTo(m);
      The return values will be result = 1
      Specified by:
      compareTo in interface Comparable<Digit>
      Parameters:
      n - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      int Returns an x value ranging from -1<x<1 where x belongs to integers. Where 0 if both are equal, 1 if n>m and -1 if n<m.
      Since:
      v0.0.3
      See Also:
      • Comparable.compareTo(Object)
      • compareIntegerParts(String, String)
      • compareDecimalParts(String, String)

    • compareToZero

      public int compareToZero()
      Compares a Digit instance to zero.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit(1);

			int result = n.compareToZero();
      The return values will be result = 1
      Returns:
      int Returns an x value ranging from -1<x<1 where x belongs to integers. Where 0 if is equals to zero, 1 if n>0 and -1 if n<0.
      Since:
      v0.0.5

    • negate

      public Digit negate()
      Creates a Digit instance with the boolean isNegative attribute negated.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit(1);
			Digit m = n.negate();
      The return values will be m = -1
      Returns:
      Digit Returns the negated value for the Digit instance.
      Since:

    • abs

      public Digit abs()
      Creates a Digit instance with the boolean isNegative attribute on false.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit(-1);
			Digit m = n.abs();
      The return values will be m = 1
      Returns:
      Digit Returns the absolute value for the Digit instance.

    • add

      public Digit add(Digit other)
      Adds two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit("-123.45");
			Digit m = new Digit(678.9);

			Digit result = n.add(m);
      The return values will be result = 555.45
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the addition of the two instance.
      Since:
      v0.0.4
      See Also:
      • negate()
      • abs()
      • padZerosRight(String, int)
      • addition(int, String[], boolean)

    • multiply

      public Digit multiply(Digit other)
      Multiplies two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit("25");
			Digit m = new Digit(5);

			Digit result = n.multiply(m);
      The return values will be result = 125
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the multiplication of the two instance.
      Since:
      v0.0.5
      See Also:
